metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: C++ Algorithm
C++ Algorithms
In the previous chapters, you learned that data structures (like vectors , lists , etc) are used to store and organize data.
content.html: In the previous chapters, you learned that data structures (like vectors, lists, etc) are used to store and organize data.

content.text: Algorithms are used to solve problems by sorting, searching, and manipulating data structures.
content.html: Algorithms are used to solve problems by sorting, searching, and manipulating data structures.

content.text: The <algorithm> library provides many useful functions to perform these tasks with iterators .
content.html: The <algorithm> library provides many useful functions to perform these tasks with iterators.

content.text: To use these functions, you must include the <algorithm> header file:
content.html: To use these functions, you must include the <algorithm> header file:

content.code_html:
// Include the algorithm library
#include <algorithm>

content.text: Sorting Algorithms
To sort elements in a data structure, you can use the sort() function.
content.html: To sort elements in a data structure, you can use the sort() function.

content.text: The sort() function takes iterators (typically a start iterator returned by begin() and an end iterator returned by end() ) as parameters:
content.html: The sort() function takes iterators (typically a start iterator returned by begin() and an end iterator returned by end()) as parameters:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Sort cars alphabeticallysort(cars.begin(), cars.end());
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW",
"Ford", "Mazda"};// Sort cars alphabeticallysort(cars.begin(), cars.end());

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
 "Ford", "Mazda"};// Sort cars alphabeticallysort(cars.begin(), cars.end());
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Sort cars alphabetically
sort(cars.begin(), cars.end());

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a vector called cars that will store stringsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Sort cars alphabeticallysort(cars.begin(), cars.end());
// Create a vector called cars that will store strings

content.text: By default, the elements are sorted in ascending order. In the example above, the elements are sorted alphabetically since they are strings.
content.html: By default, the elements are sorted in ascending order. In the example above, the elements are sorted alphabetically since they are strings.

content.text: If we had a vector of integers, they would be sorted numerically:
content.html: If we had a vector of integers, they would be sorted numerically:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers numericallysort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers numericallysort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers numericallysort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Sort numbers numerically
sort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers numericallysort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.text: To reverse the order, you can use rbegin() and rend() instead of begin() and end() :
content.html: To reverse the order, you can use rbegin() and rend() instead of begin() and end():

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse ordersort(numbers.rbegin(), numbers.rend());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse order

content.code:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers
numerically in reverse ordersort(numbers.rbegin(), numbers.rend());

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse ordersort(numbers.rbegin(), numbers.rend());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse order

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Sort numbers numerically in reverse order
sort(numbers.rbegin(), numbers.rend());

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse ordersort(numbers.rbegin(), numbers.rend());
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers 
  numerically in reverse order

content.text: To only sort specific elements, you could write:
content.html: To only sort specific elements, you could write:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers numerically, starting 
  from the fourth element (only sort 5, 9, and 2)

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers numerically, starting 
  from the fourth element (only sort 5, 9, and 2)

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Sort numbers numerically, starting from the fourth element (only sort 5, 9, and 2)
sort(numbers.begin() + 3, numbers.end());

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Sort numbers numerically, starting 
  from the fourth element (only sort 5, 9, and 2)

content.text: Searching Algorithms
To search for specific elements in a vector, you can use the find() function.
content.html: To search for specific elements in a vector, you can use the find() function.

content.text: It takes three parameters: start_iterator , end_iterator , value , where value is the value to search for:
content.html: It takes three parameters: start_iterator, end_iterator, value, where value is the value to search for:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> 
  numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Search for the number 3auto it = find(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 3);
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int>
numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Search for the number 3auto it = find(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 3);

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> 
  numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Search for the number 3auto it = find(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 3);
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Search for the number 3
auto it = find(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 3);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integersvector<int> 
  numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};// Search for the number 3auto it = find(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 3);
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.text: To search for the first element that is greater than a specific value, you can use the upper_bound() function:
content.html: To search for the first element that is greater than a specific value, you can use the upper_bound() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
// Sort the vector in ascending order

// Find the first value that is greater 
  than 5 in the sorted vector

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
// Sort the vector in ascending order

// Find the first value that is greater 
  than 5 in the sorted vector

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Sort the vector in ascending order
 sort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());

// Find the first value that is greater than 5 in the sorted vector
auto it = upper_bound(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 5);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
// Sort the vector in ascending order

// Find the first value that is greater 
  than 5 in the sorted vector

content.text: The upper_bound() function is typically used on sorted data structures. That's why we first sort the vector in the example above.
content.html: The upper_bound() function is typically used on sorted data structures. That's why we first sort the vector in the example above.

content.text: To find the smallest element in a vector, use the min_element() function:
content.html: To find the smallest element in a vector, use the min_element() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Find the smallest number
auto it = min_element(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.text: To find the largest element, use the max_element() function:
content.html: To find the largest element, use the max_element() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Find the largest number
auto it = max_element(numbers.begin(), numbers.end());

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

content.text: Modifying Algorithms
To copy elements from one vector to another, you can use the copy() function:
content.html: To copy elements from one vector to another, you can use the copy() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Create a vector called copiedNumbers 
  that should store 6 integers

// 
  Copy elements from numbers to copiedNumbers

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Create a vector called copiedNumbers 
  that should store 6 integers

// 
  Copy elements from numbers to copiedNumbers

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store integers
vector<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 5, 9, 2};

// Create a vector called copiedNumbers that should store 6 integers
vector<int> copiedNumbers(6);

// Copy elements from numbers to copiedNumbers
copy(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), copiedNumbers.begin());

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store integers

// Create a vector called copiedNumbers 
  that should store 6 integers

// 
  Copy elements from numbers to copiedNumbers

content.text: To fill all elements in a vector with a value, you can use the fill() function:
content.html: To fill all elements in a vector with a value, you can use the fill() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store 6 integers

// Fill all elements in the numbers vector with the value 
  35

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store 6 integers

// Fill all elements in the numbers vector with the value 
  35

content.code_html:
// Create a vector called numbers that will store 6 integers
vector<int> numbers(6);

// Fill all elements in the numbers vector with the value 35
fill(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 35);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a vector called numbers that will store 6 integers

// Fill all elements in the numbers vector with the value 
  35

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What does the sort() function do?
content.html: What does the sort() function do?

metadata.question: What does the sort() function do?

options.text: Sorts elements in ascending order by default
Sorts elements in descending order by default

content.question: What does the sort() function do?

options.text: Sorts elements in ascending order by default
Sorts elements in descending order by default

content.html: For a complete reference of algorithm functions, go to our C++ Algorithm Reference.
